Number and type of infrastructure projects implemented; number of training events conducted and number of people trained across the various sectors by the project; food crop productivity and diversification; farm and off-farm income level; mobile phone connectivity across the district.

comment.narrative: At the time of the start of project implementation in 2008, there was only 3 primary health clinics in the entire district; no health center; large section of the district has no primary health facilities; 31 primary school buildings with at least 50% using makeshift structures; no high school; only about 10% of all instructional staff members hold teacher training certificates and on government payroll; no science laboratories on any school; no concrete bridges in any part of the district; no lighting in the clinics; only about 20% of all hand pumps constructed were functioning; few community water and sanitation management committees but not functioning; food crop production - rice, cassava, fruits and vegetables - are extremely low to the point that most of the food requirements are met through import from other districts and counties; and wealth community participation and local governance .
Clear outstanding commitments.
Completed outstanding payments to contractors. Project has been operational closed; preparing for Project Review Meeting to financially closed the project.

description.narrative: Improving prosecution Services

This Project is designed to increase public confidence in the criminal justice system’s ability to provide redress by addressing weaknesses in the prosecution element of the criminal justice system stemming from lack of qualified and properly trained prosecutors which inhibits their ability to effectively and justly perform their role.
capital of a political entity

•The Ministry of Justice's internal management is enhanced and there is greater efficiency of its utilization of resources and personnel •Prosecutors are effectively trained in procedural and substantive areas in order to enhance justice delivery to the community, and donor funding is coordinated to eliminate duplication and maximize impact of training activities •Standard operating procedures are developed and put into place to create consistent application of institutional rules and regulations to promote support for the legal system, generally, and the Ministry in particular, through the creation of accountability mechanisms and the improvement in the professional delivery of services •Linkages are created between the prosecutors, the police, and the communities served by them in order to develop sustainable relationships to enhance public trust and promote public safety and justice

comment.narrative: . The Ministry of Justice – the key Government agency in this sector – lacks the resources and personnel to fulfill its role in providing due process and assuring public safety and security. Specifically, in the criminal justice system, prosecution services have been weakened by a lack of human and material resources and as a result, public safety is undermined and citizens have little faith in the ability of the criminal justice system to hold criminals accountable or to provide victims of crimes with redress.

policy, planning and administration

The Objective of the project is ‘to reduce vulnerability and build resilience of local communities and socio-economic sectors to the threats of climate change in Liberia’s coastal areas. The indicators for achieving this are: 1. Level of follow-up investment into large-scale, coastal protection projects; and 2. Number of people with improved living conditions and not subject to climate change impacts

comment.narrative: Very limited information on sea levels and coastal erosion due to lack of trained personnel and forecasting equipment in Liberia
Complete the 100 meter of bricks water revetment for coastal defense of Buchanan.
100 metre of bricks water revetment was constructed to aid the coastal defense of Buchanan. The result of this intervention has minimized sea erosion of the coastal belt of Buchanan
Conduct maintenance and back-filling of of the 100 meter construction.

description.narrative: To reduce vulnerability and build resilience of local communities and socioeconomic sectors to the threats of climate change in Liberias coastal areas
1 Level of followup investment into largescale coastal protection projects

comment.narrative: At least 20 million planned investment

As the result of the socioeconomic and environmental impacts created by the ongoing project in Buchanan the National Legislature allocated USD25 million for coastal protection in the 20152016 fiscal budget This is expected to increase as the project continue to create more positive impacts

description.narrative: 2 Number of people with improved living conditions and not subject to climate change impacts

comment.narrative: 0 currently the people are subject to flooding erosion loss of property and are living in poverty
3000 people will be removed from these conditions
More than five thousand people living on Atlantic Street in Buchanan have been impacted by the project so far Livelihood opportunities have been improved and properties protected

description.narrative: At three sites sustainable and affordable measures to protect coastal areas against climate change impacts are demonstrated

1 Rate of beach erosion and associated flooding at key sites in Liberia
The rate of beach erosion and flooding around key sites are increasing in Liberia The beach line engulfing starting from the New Kru Town onto the Hotel Africa belt constantly experience sea erosion and flood problems In recent time there has been cases of erosion of a densely populated borough of New Kru Town threatening a major Government High School in the area

comment.narrative: The three key sites currently experience 35m of beach lossyear to be confirmed after project starts Except for the Hotel Africa zone this action of turbulent erosion has now changed in some of the areas The Atlantic Street area in Buchanan where the pilot construction is now ongoing currently experiences no sea erosion The structure now serves as barrier to this action and so the shoreline segment now experiences sedimentation

At least 600m of coastline protected from this erosion By the end of the project 600 meters of shoreline covering key fishing communities Fanti and Barleh Wleh Towns along the Buchanans Atlantic Street coast will be protect ted

More than eighty percent of the rocks required for the construction of the remaining one hundred meters of break waters and revetment have been supplied Engineers are awaiting finalization of equipment contract by the GovernmentMLME to begin construction

description.narrative: 2 At the three sites the local community is maintaining the coastal protection structures that were built by the project

comment.narrative: na
Evidence that community is actively monitoring and repairing the groins with own resources
In Buchanan the city corporation regularly deployed some of its staff to brush the project site and provide security for the rocks using their own resources

description.narrative: Capacity in three coastal counties to plan and respond to climate change is strengthened
1 In three counties the County Development Agendas address climate change

comment.narrative: The CDA to not mention climate change
The next set of CDAs fully address climate change and allocate resources to CCadaptation actions

The development of the next generation of County Development Agendas has not been started by the Government however at the national level climate change is being mainstreamed in the Agenda for Transformation Additionally the 20152016 fiscal budget allocated about USD25 million for coastal adaptation This is the first time that such amount has been allocated for climate change adaptation in the country

description.narrative: 2 Availability in Liberia of skilled and unskilled womanpower to build gabion groins revetments and other lowtech coastal protection

comment.narrative: Private sector capacity to build groins etc to cover at least 2000m of coast per year

During this reporting period except for the private company that is supplying the rocks and equipment for the construction of the break waters and revetments no contributions were received from the private sector

description.narrative: Lessons learnt and best practices from Outcomes 1 2 and 3 are disseminated to stakeholders and development partners
1 Number of vulnerable communities in Liberia which have seen the lessons learned from Outcome 3 and the best practices and are starting to replicate

comment.narrative: na

One major Government Secondary School was damaged this year by coastal erosion A high level Government delegation visited the site and decided to replicate the Buchanan intervention in the affected community New Kru Town in Montserrado County The Government has already allocated some money for the intervention

description.narrative: 2 Number of contributions to the UNs Adaptive Learning Mechanism ALM

comment.narrative: na
At least 2 articles per year
One article was produced by the UNDP CO communication unit and published in major local news paper and the UNDP website

description.narrative: National level capacity to plan and respond to climate change in coastal areas is strengthened
1 Based on approved legislation Government budget appropriated to an integrated coastal management unit ICMU

comment.narrative: 0 na
The Act is approved by the national legislature and centrally addresses climate change 600000year is allocated to an ICMU

It was observed that the Ministry of Lands Mines and Energy has the mandate of protecting coastal zones As such there is no need for creating an Act for setting up an ICZMU It is already part of the mandate of the MLME So far a national consultant has been recruited to set up the ICZMU at the MLME The MLME has promised to integrate the ICZNU in its regular operation budget when set up No specific amount is known yet Already the MLME has provided the office space and will be furnished by the project

description.narrative: 2 Datainformation on sea levels and coastal erosion

comment.narrative: very limited
A database is established that covers coastal areas and is being used regularly by a number of partners and is in line with international standards
Procurement of data collection equipment is ongoing Data collection has therefore not started

title.narrative: PIMS 4439 Lib Agriculture - Enhancing Resilience to CC

description.narrative: PIMS 4439 Lib Agriculture

title.narrative: Mid-Term Evaluation of the project Enhancing Resilience to Climate Change by Mainstreaming Adaption Concerns into Agricultural Sector Development in Liberia”

description.narrative: This project is to increase resilience of poor, agriculturally-dependent communities and decrease vulnerability of agricultural sector to climate change in Liberia.
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
To increase resilience of poor agriculturaldependent communities and decrease vulnerability of agricultural sector to climate change in Liberia
change in projected food production in target areas given existing and projected climate change AMAT indicator 128

comment.narrative:
Upland Not currently measured
Lowland tonsyear of lowland rice site specific information
Baselines to be established during inception

Upland lowland Formal tracking system established to cover diversified food commodities
Lowland 10 average annual increase of rice production due to cultivation of traditional rice varieties as adaptation option
Application beyond demonstration sites due to policy upscaling actions

In 2012 a climate change vulnerability and livelihood assessment was conducted in the two pilot counties specifically in two districts Panta and Gbarzon Eight 8 demonstration sites were established eight Farmer Field Schools FFS formed with 25 farmers in each of the FFS Several potential adaptation measures were identified for testing at these sites so as to enhance resilience
In addition to the vulnerability assessment a capacity assessment of the agriculture sector was conducted in the agriculture sector to identify key climate change management needs and inform the development of a capacity development plan to manage climate change in the sector A Climate Change Management CCM Capacity Development Plan was developed for the sector with a threeprong approach a training and research capacity for sector techniciansfield staff and university students b institutional strengthening of the MOA and other sector agencies including agricultureforestry colleges and c review of policies laws and investment framework governing agriculture sector development as well as advocacy for mainstreaming climate changes into these policiesinvestments Additionally a Climate Risk Management CRM Strategy was developed informed by both the findings of the vulnerability assessment and the capacity assessment Implementation of the CCMCD Plan started in September of 2013
Since the rollout of implementation the CCMCD plan and CRM as well as the testing of innovations at the there have been significant progress toward achievement of the project key objectives These include the following
More than 200 farmers both pilot areas and non pilot towns are now aware and can relate specific climate change hazards to impacts on their farms farmers are also aware of coping measures both through the demonstration sites learning and for farmers not part of the FFS from the exchanges with FFS farmers and extension support of the MOA field staff
Framers in Panta and Gbarzon are now rightly timing key activities in the rice farming cycle including clearingpreparation of farmland planting etc This is as opposed to having to replant the rice later in the year when the previously planted seeds did not germinate because of late rains Replanting rice later in the year when germination failed was widely reported during the vulnerability assessment as a coping measure by farmers in both Panta and Gbarzon Districts of Bong and Grand Counties
Framers
Additionally about 90 of the 200 FFS farmers are now into lowland farming at their own farms as compared to about 55 when the FFS started This is a direct gain for the Ministry of Agricultures policy for more and more farmers to move into lowland farming
A strikingly impressive progress to note here is that the Ministry of Agriculture reported an increase in rice and cassava production activities between 2013 and 2014 as indicated by its record of increase in number of active framers in Bong County those with actual rice farms during the period and whose farms were visited and production authenticated According to the MOAs Annual Reports of 2013 and 2014 actual rice farmers in Bong County one of the pilot counties increased from 1413 farmers in 2013 to 5729 about 305 Women farmers constituted the larger share of this For example in 2013 the number of women farmers with actual farms in Bong County was 756 compared to 657 men For cassava Bong County recorded figure of 2712 in 2014 rising from 1033 in 2013
The MOA also reported increase in rice production activities in the other pilot county of Grand Gedeh However the increase was not as large as that of Bong Actual rice farmers in Grand Gedeh County increased from 958 501 males 457 females in 2013 to 1185 in 2014 representing 237 increase

description.narrative: Innovative sustainable socially appropriate adaptive measures piloted at the community level
of targeted households that have adopted resilient livelihoods under existing and projected climate change AMAT indicator 1311

comment.narrative:
Type and level 0
aside already exiting local coping mechanism
No of targeted households to be confirmed for each of the three demonstration site during inception of local level activities0 of targeted households is the baseline

Type and level at least 4 different innovations at each demonstration site
including the formal identification of locally existing coping strategies which are furthered and formalized as local adaptation measures
80 of targeted households have adopted resilient livelihoods at demonstration sites

A climate change vulnerability assessment a livelihood needs assessment of the impacts of climate change on farming was conducted in the two pilot counties specifically in two districts Panta and Gbarzon of Bong and Grand Gedeh Counties respectively Eight 8 towns were covered in the two districts namely Foequelleh Bellemue Garmu and Gbarngasiaquelleh Panta District Bong County and Tian Town Zleh Town Gaye Town and Puoh Town Gbarzon District Grand Gedeh County The UNFAO led the vulnerability assessment I took place from December 9 to 16 2012 Before finalizing the report the findings were validated in March 2013 in an extensively participatory process involving more than 200 farmers partner institutions including AEDE CARE UNDP etc The assessment documented climate change hazards and their impacts on farming as well as the coping measures farmers were applying at the time The study also documented vulnerabilities and alternative livelihood options farmers had in Panta and Gbarzon Adaptive measures were identified together with farmers including onse already being practiced by farmers but with slight improvements for efficiency Eight 8 demonstration sites were established in the eight towns covered and eight Farmer Field Schools FFS formed with 25 farmers in each of the FFS in each of the eight towns Eight FFS Facilitators were identified and trained facilitated by FAO to lead learning activities at the FFS Testing of innovations at the sites commence in May of 2013
Innovation Testing So far three innovations have been tested successfully at each of the eight sites The testing of innovations is being complimented by other essential trainings and awarenesssensitization activities These can be summarized as follows
Innovation Tested
Improve reliability of water supply in the swamp through establishment of water harvesting systems valley dams valley tankreservoirs with appropriate water control measures
CC Impact Being alleviate
Crop failure and low productivity due to water stress
Results
Successful in both Bong and Grand Gedeh
Innovation Tested
Reduce floods by developing water control and drainage systems
CC Impact Being alleviate
Crop failure due to flooding
Results
Successful in both Bong and Grand Gedeh Farmers well versed in this
Innovation Tested
Integrated soil fertility management through practices such as green manure legumes Nfixing agroforestry trees composting and animal manure application
CC Impact Being alleviate
Low crop productivity resulting from soil erosion and reduced fertility due to land degradation
Results
Successful in Bong and Grand Gedeh However the issue raised was the inappropriateness of the site used to test this innovation Grand Gedeh no soil degradation issue was visible at the site in one of the tows Tian Town FFS
Innovation Tested
Promote crop varieties resistant to pests and diseases
CC Impact Being alleviate
Low productivity due to increased pest and diseases
Results
IPM training Agroecosystem analysis AESA being utilized by farmers
Additionally four nonpilot towns have been reached by FAO and MOA extension officers with sensitizations of Climate change as well as lessons from the learning at demonstration sites
The MOA has planned an assessment of the pilot districts including both towns with demonstration sites and nonpilot towns to authenticateverify the following
o The kinds and number of innovations tested and the extent of learning at the FFS
o The actual number of FFS farmers adopting the innovations at their individual farms and
o The number of farmers in pilot towns which are adopting the measures on their farms as result of the outreach the projects county team

Based on the capacity assessment of the sector mentioned above a Climate Change Management CCM Capacity Development Plan was developed for the agriculture sector and implementation has been ongoing as follows 1 Forty 40 technical staff 15 women and 25 men 20 MOA 5 EPA 5 MOT 5 MIA and 5 FDA trained on the concepts nature causes issues and impacts of CC and current interventions international and national for adaptationmitigation including existing coping measures
2 fourteen 14 county level staffs integrated into project implementation teams in pilot counties to facilitate handson learning and enhance capacity to advice on CCA These include 2 County Agriculture Coordinators CACs 6 Districts Agriculture OfficersDAOs 2 County project PlannersCPPs 2 County Development OfficersCDOs 1 Field Officer of CARE and 1 Field Staff of Agency for Economic Development Empowerment
3 The two 2 leading universities University of Liberia and Cuttington University supported to revise the curricula of their colleges of agriculture forestry and sustainable development modules developed and validated for two 2 short courses on CCA to be administered every semester at the two universities and to undertake one climate change research 40 students 20 male and 20 females and 8 lecturersall male were involved in the training and research from data collection to analysis Climate change topic are now being taught in already existing courses in the department of Agriculture and Forestry University of Liberia and in the Department of Agriculture and Sustainable Development Cuttington The research was finalized and the report shared The researchstudy was done on the Biological and ScioEconomic Impacts of Climate Change on the Farming of Selected Crops in Panta and Gbarzon Districts in Liberia
42 students equally disaggregated by gender and 14 instructors all male for departments of agriculture forestry and environmental science of seven universities in Liberia were trained handson to conduct climate change riskvulnerability assessments in the agriculture sector at the Central Agriculture Research Institution CARI from on the 29th 30th April and 1st May 2015 facilitated by a national training consultant This training does not only increase knowledge of climate change but will also support the process of the National Adaptation Planning Process and the national survey on the economics of adaptation
Additionally a Climate Change Resource Center is now being set up in Bong and grand Gedeh Counties The centers will be a part of the platform for climate change learning information sharing by university and secondary school students as well as professional individuals and organizations working in the sector in these counties It will provide different kinds of information on climate change and how to manage the risks associated not only for agriculture sector but for other development sectors It will contain computers books reports of ongoing projects linkswebsites to international resources as well as other reading materials There will be conference facilities for holding symposiums and topic discussions with different interest groups Activity at the center will focus on research and community outreach The center will provide
Research facilities both online webbased and hard library of booksreading materials reports etc
Briefing services video shows for raising awareness
Public lectures topical and other discussions with communities on climate change related issues
Seminars for schools local governmentpolicy makers and private sector people
The main objective of the Resource Center is to enhance capacity of countydistrict levels stakeholders support management of risks associated with climate change through dissemination of updated and reliable information tailored to local needs

Core activities around this output could not be implemented due to the outbreak of the Ebola Virus Disease EVD and the subsequent delays in the procurement of equipment and services The Government of Liberia requested UNDP to procure equipment along with services like training installation and maintenance Because of the low level of human capital we feel that the procurement of equipment alone cannot guarantee EWS for Liberia and its long term sustainability The long term agreement LTA to be issued by CIRDA is the best option for the country The EVD also hampered other capacity building activities as experts could not come into the country and staff could not be accepted in several countries for training In 2014 negotiations with the World Meteorological Organization Training Institutions in Nigeria and Kenya collapsed because of the EVD but responses from both countries are advanced and students will be sent over by 4th quarter Probably the most substantive deliverable for the year besides training will be the renovation of the building to be used as the National Meteorological Center NMC within the premises of the Roberts International Airport This project is to begin during the 4th quarter

comment.narrative:
Recent survey (2013) results show that more than 80% of the general population have limited or no knowledge on decentralization and the benefit of share governance
Local government offices in the 15 counties do not have office space and supporting infrastructure to accommodate the MACs.
4 additional County Service Centers (CSCs) opened by December 2016. Participatory decentralization planning and budgeting processes organized in at least 2 counties.

4 County Service Centers (CSCs) were operational in 2016 providing much needed decentralized services to people in Bong, Nimba, Grand Bassa and Margibi Counties. In 2016, the Centers responded to 22,363 persons thereby generating over 12 million Liberian Dollars (about 200,000 USD).

All 15 County Service Centers (CSCs) open.
Civil society organizations disseminate information on the importance and use of the County Service Centers.

15 County Service Centers (CSCs) are operational, bringing services to people across the country. 14 services including birth certificates, driver licenses, western & traditional marriage certificates and business registrations are issued at the centers. This is important as it has generated over half a million US Dollars in revenue while creating easy access to basic social services to the populace.
To further enhance use of the CSCs, 11 CSOs had thecapacities strengthen which have led to a greater awareness of the CSCs within many rural locales.

An additional 60 MIA staff to receive professional training by September 2018. At least 20 must be female.
By September 2018, a Revenue Sharing Formula report would have been developed.
At least $125,000 allocated by Government of Liberia for operational cost of the CSCs.

Three (3) bill boards refurbished and erected at strategic locations in Montserrado to create awareness on procurement reforms; Over 10 media Houses reported on events of the International Anti-Corruption Day (IACD), held in Gbarnga City, Bong County, Liberia; at least fifteen (15) internal auditors were trained in internal auditing with 30% constituting females staff; Five (5) Student Integrity Clubs were established in five (5) assessed public high schools in Montserrado County while five (5) information bulletin boards were also erected in the five (5) assessed public high schools in Montserrado county; fifteen (15) LACC staff (14 males and 1 female) were trained in information/data collection and analysis and this has bolstered the capacity of the LACC in handling investigative cases; Four (4) staff, including three staff from LACC (one female and 2 males) and one staff from Ministry of Justice were trained at the Egerton University in Kenya in forensic science and investigation, especially in the handling of corruption cases, including in case selection, and forensic financial investigation; and established a digitized electronic database for the National Civil Society Council of Liberia.

Increase by 25% sui-moto prosecutions; increases by 25% investigations on Corruption; Conduct Capacity assessment; develop a capacity development plan specifically for increasing prosecutorial capacity and for understanding the effectiveness of Asset Disclosure system; erect 10 billboards; hold 36 radio talk shows on procurement processes; produce 5 jingles procurement processes of the PPCC; air 4,368 spots of jingles in Monrovia; air 2,496 spots of jingles in the counties; increase internet bandwidth to 10 MBps; install robust firewall; establish external access to PPCC document management system; produce ID cards and call cards for all of PPCC staff; hold at least 10 open expenditure initiative events; organize at least 2 events to create awareness on illicit financial flows in Liberia; organize one major event to talk about integrity in the civil service.

Purchased one vehicle; hired one experienced lawyer to support the LACC in its pursuit to prosecute those charged with corruption; hired and trained five (5) investigators; provided external training in forensic investigations to three (3) LACC staff; established a state-of-the-art cybercrime lab with surveillance equipment; setting up and equipping of investigative pool room with furniture and ICT equipment; and hiring of one data clerk and setting up of data clerk office with furniture and ICT equipment; supported the erection of three giant-sized billboards in locations in Montserrado and Margibi counties; supported purchase of one ID card and business card machine; procured a 10MBps internet bandwidth to increase the internet bandwidth of PPCC; procured firewall to provide internet security for PPCC e-procurement portal; and supported to development and airing of radio jingles as well as hosting of radio talk shows on E-tendering and procurement compliance processes; Through the use of CSOs the following activities were supported: Provided support to the four CSOs (FIND, IREDD, LMDI and DEN-L) to carryout various forms of engagements including debates among students, training of CBOs to engage community members, radio talk shows, jingles and dramas to increase the level of awareness surrounding accountability, transparency, integrity and corruption issues in Liberia.

1st Quarter 2016 National Launch of the SDGs Her Excellency President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, on January 26, 2017, launched the new development global framework, Agenda 2030, which replaces the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs, 2000-2015). President Sirleaf, as co-Chair of the United High Level Panel of Eminent Persons on the Post-2015 and Chair of the African Union High Level Committee of Heads of State and Government on the Post-2015.
The three-day event brought together members of the Government, Civil Society Organizations, the Private Sector, Academia, Youth and Women Organizations and the Media. The United Nations Sustainable Development Solutions Network (UN-SDSN) of Columbia University, New York and the United Nations System in Liberia collaborated with the organizers in the planning and execution of the program.
The outcome of the National Launch at the end of the two days of stakeholders’ deliberations focused on ways to create synergy and align Liberia’s development key priorities with the various global development agendas to ensure effective implementation of the SDGs. Amongst Liberia’s key priorities from the SDGs as outlined by Minister Amara Konneh, are SDG 3 (Health); SDG 4 (Education); SDG 5 (Gender Equality); SDG 6 (Clean water and sanitation); SDG 9 (Infrastructure); SDG 16 (Peace society); and SDG 17 (Global Partnership). Minister Konneh also announced the formation of an Inter-Ministerial SDGs Taskforce led by the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning.
Effective Coordination of GOL/UNDP programme The MFDP effectively managed the signing of the 2016 annual work plans were with a total of eight 10) projects’/programs’ Annual Work Plans have been signed out of 14 with four projects/programs outstanding awaiting their respective project board meetings. This has been the best ever coordination process conducting board meeting by clustering all programmes/projects under respective CPD Outcome/Pillar level which was effectively managed t

Fully equip at least 720 officers and men of the BIN and LNP to fight Ebola and maintain law and order;Cover at least 1000 EVD training for security management and other officials covering 8 counties;provide social safety net support to at least 4000 EVD affected persons in the 8 counties.

comment.narrative: Limited capability of BIN and the LNP to undertake EVD related responsibilities of quarantining communities, providing escort/protection to healthcare workers and healthcare facilities, supervising burials of victims and ensuring enhanced border surveillance within the context of the Ebola response.

Procure border surveillance logistical materials for 8 border counties to include motorcycles, rain gear, communication equipment,dinghies et al. Engage communities and security agencies for collaborative strategies for border enhancement.

Among key accomplishments made thus far are: • Enhancing the logistical capacity of the BIN and LNP via: Handing over of 16 Vehicles; 160 200cc motorbikes; 2000 infrared thermometers (to LNP, BIN, County Health Teams, IOM, Community Leaders to monitor temperature of people crossing the borders); 2000 rain gears (1,000 per LNP and BIN); 8 Public Address (PA) systems to the eight border counties for community sensitization and engagement; 16 tents and 160 camp beds for BIN and LNP to support patrols along the borders); 200 hand-held radios and 40 base radios to enhance communication of the security agencies, and 6 dinghies that have been procured to support patrol on the waters, among other. This is impacting positively on response of the security agencies to reported cases, compared to pre-project situation.
• Space created for stakeholder engagement through its well-attended and successful Focused Group Discussions (FGDs), employing the facilitation methodology that allows stakeholders to analyse border security issues, build trust and resolve to collaborate for mutual protection and development. These have been complemented with mass Community sensitization and awareness creation (CSAC) sessions that were equally well patronized and used to educate the general public on the need to collaborate with the security agencies and all partners to secure the border.
• Engagement under the project have also secured and deepened cooperation and involvement of the county authorities, including office of the County Superintendents, County Attorneys, BIN, LNP, County Health Teams, National partners as well as UNMIL, IOM, other UN Agency representatives, International NGOs, local media and community members. The space created for community members to express their views about border security. , indicating their concern about involvement of some security personnel and local authorities in illicit drug trade, and the difficulty of reporting to the same structures for redre
